title: 109_s1175
content: The Act may be cited as the "Robert M. La Follette, Sr. Commemorative Coin Act". It includes findings related to the commemorative coin. Congress finds that Robert M. La Follette, Sr., known as "Fighting Bob," was a prominent figure in American politics, serving in various roles and founding the Progressive wing of the Republican Party. He was a strong advocate for civil rights and women's suffrage, earning respect from notable figures like Frederick Douglass and Harriet Tubman Upton. Fighting Bob also played a key role in implementing the "Wisconsin Idea" at both the Federal and State level, introducing reforms in areas such as election processes, environmental conservation, and railroad regulation. Fighting Bob La Follette advocated for reforms such as environmental conservation, increased education funding, and business regulation. He was a key advocate for the Seventeenth Amendment and delivered a speech on free speech in wartime. La Follette exposed corruption in the Teapot Dome Scandal and founded a progressive magazine with his wife. He also ran for the presidency on the Progressive platform. Fighting Bob La Follette was honored for his contributions to legislative research, with a room named after him in the Library of Congress in 1985. He also had a statue representing Wisconsin in National Statuary Hall and was recognized as one of the "Five Outstanding Senators" in 1957. Additionally, a portrait of him was unveiled in the Senate. In 1959, a portrait of Fighting Bob was unveiled in the Senate Reception Room, honoring his unwavering support of ideals and pursuit of a more just government. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins in honor of Robert M. La Follette, Sr., with specific specifications. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of Robert M. La Follette, Sr.'s life and accomplishments. Each coin will have inscriptions of the coin's value, minting year, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with artists from Wisconsin and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design of the coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of Robert M. La Follette, Sr.'s life and accomplishments. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with artists from Wisconsin and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single United States Mint facility during the calendar year starting on January 1, 2006. The coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, a $10 surcharge per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount on sale prices. SEC. 7. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales deposited into US Mint Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 8. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can only be issued if payment is received, security is provided, or a guarantee of payment from a qualified institution is in place.
